Detailed Description

An object list displays 'aspects' of a collection of objects in a multi-column list control.

how to group them.

Aspects are extracted by giving the name of a method to be called or a property to be fetched. These names can be simple names or they can be dotted to chain property access e.g. "Owner.Address.Postcode". Aspects can also be extracted by installing a delegate.

Sorting by column clicking is handled automatically. Grouping by column is also handled automatically.

This list puts sort indicators in the column headers to show the column sorting direction. If you wish to replace the standard images with your own images, put entries in the small image list with the key values "sort-indicator-up" and "sort-indicator-down".

For these classes to build correctly, the project must have references to these assemblies:

  • System.Data
  • System.Design
  • System.Drawing
  • System.Windows.Forms (obviously)

Definition at line 771 of file ObjectListView.cs.

References BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.GetActualImageIndex(), BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SetSubItemImage(), and BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ShowImagesOnSubItems.

Referenced by BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.SetAllSubItemImages().

virtual void BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.PrepareAlternateBackColors (  )  [protected, virtual]

Prepare the listview to show alternate row backcolors

When groups are shown, the ordering of list items is different. In a straight list, 

lvi.Index
is the display index, and can be used to determine whether the row should be colored. But when organised by groups, 
lvi.Index
is not useable because it still refers to the position in the overall list, not the display order. So we have to walk each group and then the items in each group, counting as we go, to know at which row an item will be shown (and therefore how it should be back colored).

Reimplemented in BrightIdeasSoftware.VirtualObjectListView.

Property Documentation

bool BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ShowImagesOnSubItems [get, set]

Should the list view show images on subitems?

Under Windows, this works by sending messages to the underlying Windows control. To make this work under Mono, we would have to owner drawing the items :-(

bool BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.ShowItemCountOnGroups [get, set]

This property controls whether group labels will be suffixed with a count of items.

The format of the suffix is controlled by GroupWithItemCountFormat property

Definition at line 128 of file ObjectListView.cs.

Referenced by BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.BuildGroups().

string BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.GroupWithItemCountFormat [get, set]

When a group title has an item count, how should the lable be formatted?

The given format string can/should have two placeholders:

  • {0} - the original group title
  • {1} - the number of items in the group

"{0} [{1} items]"

Definition at line 147 of file ObjectListView.cs.

bool BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.UseAlternatingBackColors [get, set]

Should the list give a different background color to every second row?

The color of the alternate rows is given by AlternateRowBackColor.

There is a "feature" in .NET for listviews in non-full-row-select mode, where selected rows are not drawn with their correct background color.

bool BrightIdeasSoftware.ObjectListView.Frozen [get, set]

Get or set whether or not the listview is frozen. When the listview is frozen, it will not update itself.

The Frozen property is similar to the methods Freeze()/Unfreeze() except that changes to the Frozen property do not nest.

objectListView1.Frozen = false; // unfreeze the control regardless of the number of Freeze() calls

Get/set the list of columns that should be used when the list switches to tile view.

If no list of columns has been installed, this value will default to the first column plus any column where IsTileViewColumn is true.
